content.description:
Classic dihedral climbing starts off as a juggy undercling that traverses up and right then thins out to small tips and tight fingers above.

BETA: Use a 00 BD C3 or similar at the angle where the crack turns to vertical or the crack will eat your rope.
content.protection:
BD C4 #4 then #.75 and #.4 down low to thin gear above.

One old bolt and a 00 C3 for TR anchor.
content.location:
On Boulder Row, look for the taller section of rock and you’ll see a right-facing dihedral.

Just below

Happy Delirium

.

content.description: On the center of the East face start in the obvious jug and move right in to the dark crack feature and up. Avoiding the choss as best as you can on the top.
content.location: Same boulder as Grasshopper. West of the approach trail before getting to Izabella.

content.description: Sit start low on the north west corner of the boulder. Left hand in the good side pull feature, right on a low sloper. Pull on and move  left into the top moves of "Wax On"
content.location: Same boulder as Grasshopper. West of the approach trail before getting to Izabella.

content.description:
Start off the ground and move to the cool horizontal crimps. Stay on the left face, ending with a long reach to the victory jug.

The right exit is a great V1, and a bit less intimidating.
content.location: Far right side of Boulder Row

climbs.name: Thin Ice
climbs.fa: Aden Parker, Andrew Burch, Ben May, Randy Leavitt, Orion Feist

content.description: This is a clean, thin, and steep finger crack located in a narrow corridor, very reminiscent of the classic Jaws crack at Woodson. A mix of liebacking and thin finger locks with bad feet will get you to the top of this sweet splitter.
content.protection: Purple C3's - #0.4 C4's. Easy TR setup with #0.4 C4's.
content.location:
33° 1'52.95"N, 116°59'49.31"W

Located in a cave/corridor just east of the main small crag seen on the approach, and west of Slender Man. A bit hidden.

content.description: A clean, slanted finger crack under a roof with a big last move to a jug. Rock quality is excellent.
content.location: Same boulder as Goblin Crack. Just above the biggest looking crag in Boulder Row. Walk east from Izabella.

content.description: Totally classic! Super short friction slab. Similar to Bobby Brown Arete at Woodson. Test those smearing skills!
content.location: East side of Boulder Row, beneath the main boulders.

content.description:
Sit or stand start and climb the right-leaning hand crack in a shallow corner.

This is named after a comic book my son created, not the movie which came out sometime later.

This is a short lead following a cool runnel feature on bullet rock, with a very thin crack set in the back.

Mantle onto the ledge to gain access to the crack. Place a few small stoppers and pull through the crux on slopers and crimps. Funky beta through here. After the crux, the crack widens and finishes on nice tips locks and bad feet.

Done in headpoint style since the gear is a bit dicey down low.
content.protection: Small stoppers and a couple finger sized cams. 1 old bolt and #0.5 cam for anchor.
content.location: To the left of Patina Flake.

content.description: Fun slab with two distinct cruxes.Good top rope after climbing "Get into the Groove"
content.protection: Gear Anchor. bd 0.4 to bd 1 sized cams

content.description: An amazingly fun problem. Sit start on a left hand pinch and low right sidepull. Make powerful moves on slopers, work through a short sequence on crimps, then finish up the technical arete to top out.
content.location: Same boulder as Grasshopper. West of the approach trail before getting to Izabella.

content.description: Start on a good edge and pinch sidepull, work up the face with a crux high step and a few friction moves to topout.
content.location: West of Izabella, seen from the approach trail.

content.description: This route climbs a vegetated seam up the left side of one of the main crags in Boulder Row. The moves off the ground are the crux and the gear isn't great, then it eases up significantly on nice rock. Top out over left. There's room for a few more routes on this formation.
content.protection: Thin gear for the start to #2 C4. Several spots for gear anchor on top and an easy walk-off.
content.location: The biggest crag in Boulder Row. Best to approach from the west/above than from below.

content.description: This is a great mini problem following a steep seam with a few good pockets. Sit start on the lowest pod, move up the seam to good holds, then fire for the jug lip.
content.location: Near the left side of Boulder Row, directly underneath a big chimney.

content.description:
Easy lay-back climbing on a jug crack leads to a somewhat technical crux at the top.

Excellent exposure and very fun climbing.

(Named for reference only. First Ascent info is unknown at this time.)
content.protection: One bolt and finger width crack for pro up top
content.location:
33.0308 x -116.9979

This tower is just downhill from Izabella and to the West of Thin Ice

content.description: Clean, straight-in tips crack in smooth vertical stone.  If it were closer to the road this would have blood and chalk splattered all over it.  A high-quality problem destined for obscurity.
content.protection: N/A the crux is low and it's a good height for bouldering.
content.location: From the dam, follow the road 1/2 mile west around the reservoir.  Turn left and walk up the hill.  This crack is just out of view at the left end of a row of boulders 200 yards up the hill.  It faces southwest.

content.description: A large, clean fractured face stands tall on the ridge and is easy to see from the approach.  Climb ascends the left arête.
content.location: Look for the obvious fractured face on Boulder Row, SW of Thin Ice.

content.description: Sit start and climb the steep, perfect hand crack. A great splitter boulder problem.

Left slanting crack with a few fun 5.9 moves to get you established takes you to a right slanting deep groove(5.5R) with no pro in it, a few more moves and a blocky crack take you to the top. Gear Anchor. Alternate finish is up the slabby face(5.10-) to the left or the right slanting thin crack a bit further(5.10)
content.protection: small finger sized gear at the bottom, nothing in the middle. small hand sized gear for anchor.
